items.synopsis: Three people went prospecting in the West Australian outback — only one came home. Now the family are taking the investigation into their own hands.

title.children: A killer's on the loose and Britney thinks the clues are in this desert

image.altText: Donald Trump in front of an American flag

items.synopsis: According to the 49-page indictment released today, Donald Trump sent “scores” of boxes to his Mar-a-Lago property in Florida after leaving the White House. Here's what else we learned.

title.children: Boxes in the shower, in a ballroom and on the floor: What we learned from the indictment against Trump

image.altText: Skyscraper buildings seen amid orange haze.

items.synopsis: A thick, yellow-orange haze has shrouded New York for much of this week. It was a familiar sight for some of the city's Australian residents.

title.children: 'Just wait it out': An Australian in New York City says she is too familiar with this scene

image.altText: Code over a womans face in a dark room.

items.synopsis: Artificial intelligence is now part of everyday life in the modern world, even if we don't always know when and where.

title.children: Algorithms are watching as you shop, to see whether you're a criminal

image.altText: Cameron Green celebrates on his knees

items.synopsis: Cam Green's screamer helps revive Australia's fortunes as Marnus Labuschagne is rudely awoken from a nap on The Oval balcony.

title.children: Five things we learnt at the WTC Final: Green's screamer and Marnus nods off

image.altText: A three-letter logo "pwc" on a wall, with a head in shadow walking past beneath it.

items.synopsis: A "bad apple", "new systems" and "nothing to see here": Daniel Ziffer explains why the PwC conflict-of-interest scandal is giving him banking royal commission vibes.

title.children: PwC, the consulting firms, their government clients and the sound I can't stop making as I listen in

image.altText: A woman in a bright colourful jumper pushes her young child on a swing.

items.synopsis: With the cost of vital goods rising dramatically, single mother Ebony is increasingly turning to charities for help. And she's not alone, with non-profits reporting unprecedented demand for services.

title.children: Demand for support doubles amid cost-of-living crisis, non-profit says

image.altText: Colombian military pose with children for a group found in jungle, with the childrens' faces blurred

items.synopsis: Colombia's president says four siblings from an Indigenous community were found alive in the south of the country more than five weeks after the plane they were travelling in crashed in thick jungle.

title.children: Four children found alive in Colombian jungle five weeks after plane crash

image.altText: Homes are seen among flood waters that have totally covered streets, leaving only the upper parts of buildings above water.

items.synopsis: Waking to a flooded house in the middle of the night, Viktoria was in despair at the prospect of getting her elderly parents to safety without the help of the Russians occupying her town. Then a friend came to the rescue.

title.children: Ukraine claims intercepted phone call proves Russia blew up dam

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a blue suit and red tie as he speaks into a microphone at a convention.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors unseal an indictment against Donald Trump, accusing the former US president of risking some of the country's most sensitive secrets with his handling of classified documents after leaving the White House in 2021.

title.children: Nuclear secrets on documents seized: Prosecutors unseal Trump indictment ahead of court date

image.altText: An aerial view of a large industrial facility, seen in greyscale

items.synopsis: Spokesman John Kirby says the White House is concerned that Russia is "working with Iran to produce Iranian UAVs from inside Russia".

title.children: US says Russia could open a drone factory early next year, with Iran's help

image.altText: a composite image of two women with their babies

items.synopsis: Both Lindy Chamberlain and Kathleen Folbigg have now been pardoned after they were accused of the most heinous crimes, and while their stories appear similar, they also differ in major ways, a legal expert says.

title.children: Two 'serious miscarriages of justice', but the Folbigg and Chamberlain cases are very different, legal expert says

image.altText: A close up of a woman in a beanie and a jacket walking down the street.

items.synopsis: How an innovative housing solution for older women could play a key role in tackling Australia's stubborn homelessness crisis.

title.children: Building homes for women like Kathy would normally take years. This project got it done in just months

image.altText: Conservative party leadership candidate Boris Johnson covers his mouth in front of blue background.

items.synopsis: A by-election will be held in the former British prime minister's marginal seat, after Mr Johnson announced he was stepping down as a member of parliament with immediate effect.

title.children: Boris Johnson standing down from UK parliament

image.altText: Lots of people gathered at Noosa main beach with umbrellas

items.synopsis: You'll soon have a reason to sleep in or extend that weekend trip. Here's a state-by-state breakdown of who gets a public holiday.

title.children: Millions of Australians have a public holiday coming up — but it depends where you live

image.altText: A 14-year-old girl wears a football uniform and stands in front of her local footy field before her NRLW game. She's smiling.

items.synopsis: Australia is rolling out a new strategy to ensure all kids can keep doing what they love.

title.children: 'It takes a village': The price we pay to keep our kids in sport

image.altText: Graphic of Australian east coast showing Cairns and Grafton earthquakes on June 7 and 8, 2023

items.synopsis: On Thursday night a magnitude-4.2 earthquake struck 100 kilometres off the coast of Cairns, about four hours later the northern New South Wales town of Grafton also started to shake.

title.children: Two Australian east-coast cities were rattled by earthquakes. Were they linked?

image.altText: A man stands with hands in his pocket with a serious expression with a river behind him at sunset

items.synopsis: When the River Murray began to rise, the Schultz family built a fence from vineyard posts, bits of tin and shade cloth to save their home — and it worked.

title.children: 'Proud to be Australian': The fence that saved a family home from flood

image.altText: An unidentifiable woman wearing ripped jeans holding a bunch of colourful shopping bags

items.synopsis: The day after I bought my new powder blue handbag, the AMP chief economist had some harsh words for me: If people don't stop spending, the Reserve Bank will keep lifting rates until profligates like me get the message, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: To buy or not to buy: Is this a sign that capitalism is cooked?

image.altText: Two women sitting at a table covered in paper materials, holding up two miniature cockatoos and smiling

items.synopsis: One year ago, the Nadesalingam family stepped off a plane in Biloela, ending four years in detention. It was a win for the Home to Bilo campaign, but those behind it say Australia's asylum seeker policy still needs work.

title.children: One year on from Tamil family's return, Home to Bilo campaigners say fight isn't over

image.altText: A black tiny home with a wooden entrance with outdoor living set in a forest.

items.synopsis: Tiny homes are being posed as the solution to the housing crisis. From a DIY project to a professional business venture, sea containers to steel frames, wheels to skids, here's how some people are building them.

title.children: Could these snug homes built in WA open the door to more affordable living?

image.altText: A Maori woman with dark features but lighter blonde hair with a thoughtful facial expression standing outside

items.synopsis: New Zealanders on recently approved permanent resident visas call for refunds after the government streamlined their path to citizenship, making their visas virtually redundant.

title.children: Kiwis who 'got screwed in the process' of new citizenship pathway want refunds

image.altText: Washington's roaming bear pokes its tongue at police

items.synopsis: A young black bear is captured in suburban Washington, DC, after wandering backyards and sniffing around garbage cans less than 8 kilometres from the White House.

title.children: Bear captured after roaming Washington suburbs 8km from the White House

image.altText: Hands grasping a cyclone wire fence.

items.synopsis: The 15-year-old's alarming story is among a host of disturbing revelations laid bare in a damning report that found Western Australia's only juvenile detention centre is failing at every level.

title.children: Teen involved in 108 critical incidents at crisis-plagued Banksia Hill as more details of 'acute crisis' revealed

image.altText: Brett Sutton, dressed in a shirt and jacket, looks to the side as he speaks to journalists.

items.synopsis: To some, Brett Sutton was a symbol of reassurance, while to others he was a source of great frustration.

title.children: An expert says as Brett Sutton departs, Victorians farewell the face of COVID-related scientific evidence

image.altText: A woman crouches down to feed a treat to a dog in a cage

items.synopsis: Kelley Linger was struggling after leaving the ADF, so she started taking part in a program where socially isolated people help train rescue dogs.

title.children: When Kelley left the ADF, she felt lost. This program has given her purpose

image.altText: A man screams in joy on a tennis court.

items.synopsis: Carlos Alcaraz shows why he is the future of tennis with a stunning shot, but Novak Djokovic outlasts his opponent for a shot at grand slam glory.

title.children: Alcaraz hits the 'shot of the year', but Djokovic gets his chance to become the official grand slam king

image.altText: A computer keyboard lit up in red.

items.synopsis: Russian-linked cybercriminals claim to have gone through with a threat to publish troves of sensitive data, after one of Australia’s largest law firms vowed not to bend to their ransom demands.

title.children: 'ENJOY!!': Hackers claim to go through with dark web threat after law firm refuses ransom

image.altText: An animation of a black pregnant woman on a motorbike and a man dressed in a spider-man outfit running alongside

items.synopsis: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse is a big hit with audiences and critics, with an Australian animator instrumental in bringing to life one of the film's most talked-about characters.

title.children: Spider-Man animator gives that one tip that might make all the difference to budding animators

image.altText: A man in dark shirt and shorts raises arms, smiling in front of a large black double-decker bus

items.synopsis: Mighty Brutus is "luxury on wheels" says owner James as he looks forward to a life of travelling.

title.children: James and his double-decker bus 'Brutus' ditch the big city for life on the road
